author: Brandon Marcello | bmarcello@al.com
title: Auburn's Mr. Wildcat is a freshman with speed
text:
Auburn's Mr. Wildcat is a freshman with speed San Jose State vs. Auburn Auburn running back Kerryon Johnson (21) lines up in the Wildcat and takes a snap from Auburn offensive lineman Austin Golson (73) against San Jose State during the first half Saturday, Oct. 3, 2015, at Jordan-Hare Stadium in Auburn, Ala. (Julie Bennett/jbennett@al.com) (JULIE BENNETT) Comments 
Tim Horton was right. 
The Auburn running backs coach wasn't sure when, but Kerryon Johnson, he said in August, would play multiple positions at some point as a true freshman. 
The running back has done more than that five games into the season. He's Auburn's No. 1 option at Wildcat quarterback, providing the former Madison Academy star plenty of opportunities to use his speed to chew up big yards. 
"That's something that he'll be very good at," Auburn offensive coordinator Rhett Lashlee said. "He did versions of it in high school, so he's caught snaps before. He's comfortable with it. Obviously we have a lot of experience with that kind of stuff and we think he fits it very well." 
Johnson led the Tigers' offense in the Wildcat package six times in their 35-21 victory against San Jose State on Oct. 3. He carried the ball five times for 21 yards. 
Johnson has played no less than three positions this season at receiver running back and Wildcat quarterback. He made one mistake in the Wildcat as he improperly motioned a player over, which resulted in center Austin Golson snapping the ball. 
"That's something that can't happen but I think now that we have a game under our belt it won't," Lashlee said. 
Johnson had five carries for 28 yards and three catches for 32 yards in a 17-9 loss to Mississippi State. "He doesn't drop balls," Horton said in August. 
Johnson also has three kick returns for 98 yards -- all against LSU in a 45-21 loss in Week 3. 
Johnson and receiver Jason Smith, a former quarterback on the junior college and high school level, are taking snaps at Wildcat quarterback, quarterback Sean White said last week. Smith did not take a snap at Wildcat against San Jose State. For now, Johnson is Auburn's Mr. Wildcat. 
"For the first game doing it, I thought he did a nice job and I think he'll get better and better at it," Lashlee said.
